title: Synergistic Targeting of BTK and Smoking-Induced TNF-α Pathways to Mitigate Joint Damage in RA
text: We hypothesize that in rheumatoid arthritis, BTK inhibitors not only suppress B cell receptor‐mediated autoantibody production but also counteract smoking-induced epigenetic modifications in T cells that elevate TNF-α. This reduction in TNF-α levels is expected to attenuate NF-κB activation, thereby decreasing MMP expression in synovial fibroblasts, ultimately reducing cartilage extracellular matrix degradation, joint damage, and bone resorption. Testing this dual mechanism may provide a synergistic therapeutic strategy for RA.

mechanistic_summaries.path_summary: The BTK Inhibitors target the Bruton's Tyrosine Kinase (BTK), which is associated with the B cell receptor signaling pathway. This pathway is involved in autoantibody production in rheumatoid arthritis, which is influenced by epigenetic modifications in T cells. These modifications are in turn influenced by environmental factors such as smoking, leading to increased production of pro-inflammatory cytokines like TNF-alpha. TNF-alpha activates the NF-kappa B signaling pathway, which modulates the expression of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) in synovial fibroblasts. The expression of MMPs contributes to the degradation of cartilage extracellular matrix in joint tissue, ultimately leading to joint damage and deformities in rheumatoid arthritis. These joint damages correlate with increased bone resorption markers like CTX-I in serum.

key_entities.definition: BTK inhibitors are compounds that block Bruton Tyrosine Kinase, a non-receptor protein implicated in signaling pathways that affect cell growth, differentiation, and malignancy in various cancers, aiding in the treatment of conditions like chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

Non-receptor tyrosine-protein kinase involved in signaling pathways that regulate differentiation and maintenance of epithelia, as well as tumor growth. It has roles in apoptosis and can contribute to cancer progression by enhancing proliferation and invasion.

The B cell receptor signaling pathway is a critical mechanism in B cell activation, proliferation, differentiation, and apoptosis, regulating immune responses and self-tolerance. It involves various receptors and signaling cascades, including those initiated by the B cell receptor itself.

Autoantibody production in rheumatoid arthritis refers to the generation of antibodies that target the body's own proteins, playing a crucial role in the pathogenesis of this autoimmune disease characterized by chronic inflammation and joint damage.

Histone deacetylase that influences transcriptional regulation and chromatin remodeling in T cells by deacetylating lysines on histones, supporting epigenetic modifications essential for T cell function and immune response.
Environmental factors such as smoking significantly contribute to various health conditions, including respiratory diseases and cancers, through the introduction of harmful chemicals into the body.

Cytokine that binds to TNFRSF1A/TNFR1 and TNFRSF1B/TNFBR, secreted mainly by macrophages. It induces cell death of tumor cells, stimulates fever, promotes insulin resistance, and plays a role in angiogenesis and osteoclastogenesis.

The NF-kappa B signaling pathway is crucial for immune response, initiated by various receptors like TLRs. It involves complex interactions leading to the nuclear translocation and activation of NF-kappa B, influencing inflammation and immunity.

key_entities.entity: expression of matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) in synovial fibroblasts
key_entities.definition: Matrix metalloproteinases (MMPs) are a group of enzymes responsible for the degradation of extracellular matrix components, playing a crucial role in tissue remodeling and inflammation. They are often expressed in synovial fibroblasts during pathological conditions such as arthritis.

key_entities.entity: degradation of cartilage extracellular matrix in joint tissue
key_entities.definition: Enzymes involved in cartilage extracellular matrix degradation play roles in tissue remodeling, bone development, and wound healing by cleaving collagen and regulating proteins. They are essential for normal bone development and contribute to processes like keratinocyte migration and tumor invasion.

key_entities.entity: joint damage and deformities in rheumatoid arthritis
key_entities.definition: Joint damage and deformities in rheumatoid arthritis result from chronic inflammation, leading to joint erosion, cartilage degradation, and structural alterations. This autoimmune disorder primarily affects synovial joints, causing pain, swelling, and eventual loss of function.

key_entities.entity: increased bone resorption markers like CTX-I in serum
key_entities.definition: CTX-I is a marker of bone resorption; its elevated levels indicate increased bone degradation activity. It can serve as a diagnostic and monitoring tool for conditions like osteoporosis and other metabolic bone diseases.
synonyms: C-terminal telopeptide of type I collagen
